commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Ruler's length?  (5)
2. Mistake "air" for "heir," say  (3)
3. Case of emergency?  (3)(4)
4. Crime ring, for short?  (3)
5. Reds' fandom?  (10)


REIGN
ERR
ALL CAPS
APB
OENOPHILIA

If a chicken drives a car, it's poultry in motion.

(But its vehicle is manual - it has a clutch!)

Until I caught on to the theme I had GOLDBUDGET instead of GOLDNUGGET. Honestly think except for the theme both would work.Nice to see PUEBLO instead of the standard utes or hopi. Wanted GOURD instead of GRAVY. Nice puzzle. 3:43 under my average. Timing was nice, just finished watching Team USA win gold in the Team figure skating competition. Like that the medal ceremony was immediately after this year.
Are the emus afraid of other birds? I tried to reply to Mike mentioning one.

The theme in 55A took me back to Michael J. Fox playing Marty McFly in the ‚ÄúBack To The Future‚Äù trilogy, who would always react strongly when anybody called him ‚Äúchicken‚Äù: https://tinyurl.com/2t7vzn5n
Finished in my PB for a Monday while watching the Superbowl. Appropriate theme, considering I had to wing it for supper.
Finished this while watching the Pooper Bowl! Nice puzzle, too! :)
Loved this theme! Lively clues, and a Monday PB for me of 3:19. Great start to the week!
Wow. Lightning fast today. I blinked and it was over.

Not much to say about today‚Äôs puzzle‚Äîstandard Monday fair, nice theme that I didn‚Äôt figure out until the revealer. I will say I quite enjoyed Miq‚Äôs commentary, engaging and colorful, I hope you come back. Like Miq I started with IOTA, and not that it‚Äôs worth nitpicking on a Monday but really ‚ÄúTHE slightest bit‚Äù is specific, which could be IOTA,  whereas ATAD is general  and obviously one can have a slight-er bit than A TAD. Again, not that anyone cares on a Monday with obvious crosses, but I bet it did mess up some folks‚Äô attempts to see how far they could get on acrosses only.

Welcome to Wordplay, Myq. Your column was entertaining. 
Quick solve while watching our team flounder in the game ü§¶üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è We even changed our jerseys after halftime, and they finally scored ü§£ Anyhoo, we did have CHICKEN wings in our spread today for the SB party we are hosting. 
Thank you for the nice distraction, Matthew. It was much needed tonight üòâ

My previous Monday best was 2:26. 

2:25 today, baby!

Here's a clue to honor the most delicious dinner I had today from my local DoorDash: 

[Creepy film from1971] 

ACLOCKWORKORANGE

 Get it? It comes with rice.
This one was all gravy.  Yum.
FLG!
What a breeze! Got my best Monday time ever (3:33).

Who won the Super Bowl? my wife asked.

Bad Bunny, I answered. It was true.

Oh that's good, she said, and went back to sleep.

I felt for the Patriots, though I rejoiced that they lost. If I were that quarterback, so youthful he still had acne, I wouldn't want to face an orca nonet with two in the backfield, it would be a lost cause. It was a no win situation for the Patriots; they had no offensive line to protect the dear boy. All coach Vrabel could do is wonder the sidelines with his clipboard in rags, giving a yell every now and then. It was a large order to fill. 

Had to say there were an awful lot of tech commercials pitching AI. Soon a bot will be in charge of all our brains. And I admit to being a tad uncomfortable with that future. If a self driving car stopped in a rainstorm and a robot offered me a ride, I'd just say no, I'm out. I'd take a gap year at that point, you'd find me in the seas, off-grid (but not THESE grids!)... yup, none of that AI for me (although it did help me use a VPN to watch the Australian Open, so OK I'm no orthodox luddite), but do we have to give up our independence to a rum bunch of tech billionaires who erase any creed or honor code they see in their quest to extract the last gold nugget from the earth,  the last gem from your ear? 

All those celebs hawking stuff we don't need. What are Jost and Che doing touting online gambling?

I solved this one 18% faster than my Monday average in between plays of the Super Bowl (and with a house full of guests).  I was sitting in a corner, so no one knew what I was doing on my phone (as most of them had their phones out for various reasons as well).

I did stop the timer by turning the screen off when I was watching plays and not solving.

But the tendency to produce very easy puzzles continues.

To my Patriot fan friends...

The Seattle defense was just too powerful for your young quarterback.  But I'm guessing this is just the start of what he and his team are going to end up doing.

I'd trade New England's football outlook for Minnesota's any time.

Much sprightlier clueing than the average Monday, I must say.

Cheers, Mr. Stock and editors.

Monday PB

Quick and breezy.  My only niggle was the torturous phrasing in the clue for the revealer.

I‚Äôm just here to celebrate Se√±or GATO‚Äôs inclusion in the puzzle. 

Go Hawks!
As a native speaker of English for 88 or 89 years, I wonder why the phrases "chicken strip," "chicken nugget," and "chicken tender" are new to me.
Got a record on the puzzle. Loved the article Myq I am vegan too! <3
Huh, always thought it was yo ho ho and a bottle of rye.

I have a confession.

The answer GAP YEAR really annoys me.  It reeks of privilege and wealth.

No offense if you took a gap year, but I had to get on with it  because only by getting on with it as quickly as possible was I able to survive the cost, both real costs and opportunity costs, was by getting through my education as quickly as possible.

I wish I'd had the luxury of spending a year touring Europe.

Yes, I'm envious.

A good one for the ‚Äúacross clues only‚Äù club. I managed it in 15:17 without looking at any down clues. (This is purely for us value-for-money masochists who enjoy the tantalizing tip-of-the-tongue torture that comes from a clue that makes you say ‚ÄúI know this‚Ä¶ I know this!‚Äù  And you have to really work at it. You‚Äôll find no 2 minute records here!)
Pretty sure the gold pieces in a pan are waaaay smaller than nuggets.

Today is my birthday! And I‚Äôm from St. Louis! On my 21st birthday, I took off work and went up the 15A just for fun.  It‚Äôs brilliant up there.  As a kid, I  imagined careening down it like a slide.  Now, I love being able to spot it from just about anywhere in the city.  And bonus - it reminds me of my birthday! 

I love sharing food and tasty treats with my friends and family, too. Especially today.  Thanks for a fun puzzle, Matthew!

I feel like I should have outgrown the appeal of a nice crispy -CHICKEN -TENDER by now, but I definitely have not. (I don‚Äôt know the difference between a -TENDER and a -STRIP. I could take or leave a -NUGGET)

A breezy solve on a frigid morning. Solving soundtrack: Phil Cook‚Äôs Appalachia Borealis

My second daily PB in a row. Judging by other people's comments yesterday and today, I suspect that I'm not going to be the only one with this particular double.

And it had been some weeks or possibly months since my previous PB even with my working backwards through old crosswords too.

Tho, today'th theme ith CHICKEN partth?

[Thigh]
Felt a bit undeservedly smug for having learned NONET üé∏ü™âüé∫üé∑üéªü™óüéπü™áü™ò recently when it was a ‚ÄúQuantfiers‚Äù theme word for Wordle.
Okay, I have heard of a "chicken nugget" and a "chicken tender," but a "chicken gas strip"? First Bad Bunny, and now this. It's all getting go be too much.

[Answer to the question ‚ÄúAre you chicken, goal tender?‚Äù by a ten-year-old who has forgotten to bring his end-of-47A to the rink.]

ATAD


.

Matthew mentioned in his notes that his grids often include a host of food-related entries, and yes ‚Äì aside from the theme answers, there‚Äôs GRAVY, DIET, ICEES, ATE, GORGE and ORDER (as clued).

This was a Monday made by a pro:
‚Ä¢	 Only a few answers that newer solvers may not have run across before and all those are easily crossed.  
‚Ä¢	All the longs are lovely ‚Äì every theme answer plus the four long downs LOST CAUSE, DIVVIED UP, HONOR CODE, and CLIPBOARD.  
‚Ä¢	The popping-fresh theme, with all its answers aside from GOALTENDER being NYT debuts.

Plus, some sweet serendipities.  YUM crossing RUM, the high-volume cross of LOL and YELL, the PuzzPair¬©Ô∏è of I'M OUT and SCAB, and even a rare-in-crosswords five-letter semordnilap (NONET).  I also liked all the OR sounds ‚Äì OAR, GORGE, ADORE, ORC, CLIPBOARD, and ORDER.

I enjoyed guessing at the revealer, not to mention the feeling throughout that I was coursing through quality.  Excellent one, Matthew, and thank you!

Another trip down memory lane when I read the clue for 28A "Body part that can serve as a pencil holder." As a very small child, there were really no stores like the supermarkets of today. Rather, they were the equivalent of the neighborhood bodega. I use to love to go around the corner to Harry's grocery. Mom would bring the items up to the register, and he'd whip that pencil from his ear and write down the cost of each on the brown paper bag, then add them up at lightning speed. He was much faster than his old cash register, and he never made a mistake. Contrast with today's clerks, who can't make change for a dollar even when the amount is staring them in the face.

A pleasant solve indeed.  [Outdoor John?] evokes the thought of that experience on sub-zero mornings, yikes!

Playing with the themers . . .

["Did you hear the only 'gentlemen's' club closed?]

LASTVEGASSTRIP

[Actor Elliot's favorite joke?]

GOULDNUGGET

[Just.  Melt.]

GO ALL TENDER

["C'mon, you can do it!"]

DARE YOU, CHICKEN

Nice Monday puzzle. Fairly smooth solve, and it wasn't until I was almost done that the theme finally dawned on me. That's always a nice touch. Puzzle find today - a Wednesday from December 7, 2016 by David Steinberg. Five answers with starred clues - each of them quite straightforwardly clued: FIXEDCOST LEFTHANDED CUTROSE SHOTPUT LOSTGROUND And then the... reveal: "Like either word in the answer to the five starred clues." PASTTENSE Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=12/7/2016&g=38&d=A ...

[Be available on short notice]


WAIT IN THE WINGS

A theme that elicits a genuinely amused smile.  That's about as good as it gets on a Monday.

I can't help but smile when I think of a fried STRIP of white meat being asked, "ARE YOU CHICKEN?" 
And responding, "Why, yes.  Yes, I am.  Can't you tell?"

Yes, STRIPS and TENDERS are surely CHICKEN.  But I'm not at all sure about some of the NUGGETS I've had.  Thank the Deity for the dipping sauce.

And no CHICKEN fingers???  I've spent too much time in my life looking for the "fingers" on chickens!

Today's puzzle was easy, even for a Monday, but I'm happy to get a smile out of it.

You know, if you buy a whole CHICKEN and cut it up, none of the pieces are STRIPS, NUGGETS, or TENDERS.  Just sayin'....

DHubby does most of the grocery shopping, and I pretty much hate when he buys CHICKEN pieces; BUTCHERED is the right word.  Even Alton Brown (who cuts a chicken into 8 pieces, gets it wrong, IMHO.  The breast should be in 3 pieces... and is he discarding the wings or back (2 pcs)?
I notice a lot of recipes lately call for a "rotisserie chicken.'  Srsly?

Other than that...nice little Monday morsel.

Last night I checked back and was very entertained by the MOONSHINE Comments.  Barry Ancona found  a photo of the fanciest still in the South!
I'll see y'all in the funny papers.
Never thought I'd say this about a NYT puzzle but this was easy-peasy. Just the right number of sorta tricky answers, and a fun and tasty theme! Thanks for starting my week off with a win!

One more rather amazing puzzle find. A Sunday from May 12, 2013 by David J. Kahn with the title "Simply put." The across theme answers: POTENTIALCONSEQUENCES OFAPLANORDECISIONONE CANNOTREVERSESHOULDBE HEEDEDPRIORTOTHETIME ANACTIONISEFFECTUATED And then one more theme answer down the middle of the puzzle: "This puzzle's long-winded advice, simply put." LOOKBEFOREYOULEAP Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/12/2013&g=24&d=D ...

My favorite Gordon Ramsay meme:
"Why did the chicken cross the road?
Because it was (expletive) RAW!"

After almost a year of crosswording finally got my first sub-5 minute solve this morning. A big thank you to all the columnists, commenters, and most of all the setters who made this day possible. Folks like you all with a passion for language and the written word are an invaluable asset to humanity. On to sub-4!

I was stopped by 20 Across. The name is Las Vegas Boulevard South, but obviously that wouldn't fit. I entered Las Vegas and got the rest from the crosses. I've only ever heard it referred to commonly as "The Strip," but "Las Vegas Strip" does come up on a search, so ... TIL

A nice and breezy Monday; entertaining and very little glue, what more could you ask?
Outdoor John made me smile, even though our ancient tractor is a Massey Ferguson. 

We‚Äôre getting a dozen Icelandic sheep this week. Not for keeps, just helping a friend with winter pasture, but it‚Äôll be lovely looking out at field of fluffy white creatures for a few weeks. The Alpacas will be livid, as the field in question has lush grass, but the girls aren‚Äôt allowed in as they‚Äôd eat our baby woodland. Sorry girls, you‚Äôll just have to glare over the fence at them.

Welcome, Myq, and thank you for helping me reframe Mondays -- I enjoyed your commentary! 

OH HI, Matthew, and thank you for a nice way to EASE into the week. I was 11 seconds off of my personal best, but blame it on still licking my wounds from a brutal Patriots loss last night. Thankfully, I was AWED by Bad Bunny's spectacular half-time show!

Happy Monday, everyone!

At the supermarket, you have your choice of CHICKEN Broth and CHICKEN Stock. Today, the NYT xwp provided us the more flavorful option. As often touted, this helping of CHICKEN Soup is better than Penicillin.
Minimal advance notice required to come over for a bowlful with matzoh balls, which  I pep up with ginger and sesame oil.

As Oliver GOLDNUGGETsmith has written: She soups to conquer

I'm still trying to do a Monday without any help, but no, not yet. Not that I thought it was that difficult, just got stuck a couple of times. I just couldn't get LAS VEGAS STRIP even with a few crossers. Having "divided up" didn't help. Having "keeper" didn't help either.

I know of the TORAH but assumed that the scroll must be something especially for the ceremony so didn't try it until later. 

I don't associate tender or strip with chicken (I have heard of nuggets but not eaten one fortunately).

Maybe next week.
Really interesting Monday. I breezed through it, but then it turned out that several of my "obvious" answers were wrong and I had to pay closer attention.

Definitely a nice way to ease into the week. I too started off with a confident IOTA, until spotting ANGLO and TORAH. Very cute theme, even for this (mostly) vegan too ;) I also liked the nudge to share more joy with the special people in our lives- a beautiful reminder.

Chicken - growing up my mother made only broiled legs & thighs. I HATED chicken! 
Age 16: Went to a boyfriend's house for dinner, and, oh no- chicken! 
It was delicious. 
I said "I've never had chicken this shape before. What do you call it?"
"Ummm breast." 
True story.

Just wondering:
Do the chicken sexers we learned about a few puzzles back start out their first few months with this easier question?
Hey columnist Myq: I'm also vegan, am also a child of professional string musicians, and also grew up dreading violin lessons! Were we separated at birth?? :-)
-KEEPER before looking at the revealer and a typo elsewhere caused me 4 secs off my PB boo!

TRIREME?  On a Monday!?

‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è

I had the first two theme clues solved and assumed the theme was about Vegas/gambling, so when I got to the revealer I felt confident the answer was DOYOUFEELLUCKY. Only problem was it‚Äôs one letter too long for the boxes. So I printed out the puzzle and drew an additional box at the end. Worked like a charm brah.
ATB at 5:45 on this one
Nice! A little tougher than a typical Monday puzzle but a lot of fun.
Great column Myq! Makes a lot of sense that your terrific word play in your comedy lends itself well to crosswords and to Wordplay. Hope to see your byline here again
That was a really cute grid. Thanks!

This is getting a little ridiculous. I finished Sunday's puzzle in 18 minutes (average 47) and Monday's puzzle in 3.5 (average 7), both personal bests. I honestly didn't think it was possible to type entries in this quickly. And yes, I got the theme. I fact, I got all the theme entries on the first pass with out crosses and immediately recognize that the revealer would be chicken related.

The NYT crossword is not the challenge that it used to be.

My favorite encore clues from last week:

[Not fair, in a way]  (7)
[More ideal?]  (6)


RAINING
UTOPIA

@Mike

When a rooster drives a shuttle, it's coq au van.
@Mike Poultry in motion!! Brilliant. Your jokes about chickens leave me in raptors!

Mike,

‚ÄúAny available officers: if you see a chicken driving a car,
pullet over.‚Äù

OK, @Mike

When is a CHICKEN like Superman?
.... When it has its CAPON.

@Mike

Those are some clucking good puns.

@Mike
If he sings along with a top 10 hit on the radio, does he Chanticleer winner?

Mike,

No turkeys from you.

(And we won't egg you on.)

I guess they are. 

I also said we didn't egg him on.
And that he's no turkey?
So they were okay in an OP but not a reply? Gotta love this comments system.

Barry Ancona, Not everyone agrees. They are loveable my many. Loveability Easy Median Like Time 1:42 Median Likers 37% more than OPs ‚ö°63% of users love the comments more than their usual average. 39% love faster (>20%) than their other commenters üê¢8% of users loved slower than their usual average. 2% loved much slower (>10%) than their usual average. https://cmtstats.com/puzzles/2026-02-09 (I just couldn't resist, sorry) üòâ

Jerry,
You will appreciate that said bird liberated the reply 15 minutes ago. Must have been in the 2% much slower group.
@Madeline awesome üèéÔ∏èüí®
@SP I entered A TAD right off the bat. I probably should have gone with iota, but it didn‚Äôt occur to me ü§∑üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èü§¶üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

@SP

Iota here too.  Not surprised to have to go back and change it, but also felt slightly disgruntled, because ATAD was not really slight enough.

@SP

What was nice about the theme? The convoluted, awkwardly worded revealer? Or maybe the random phrases that happened to include names for chicken products? And if not that then perhaps how the theme was completely immaterial to the solve because it was so easy my dog could probably do it?

@Andrzej

Understand, ‚Äúnice‚Äù to me means reasonably unobjectionable and pleasant but not necessarily outstanding or remarkable. I mean it‚Äôs about as typical a Monday theme as you can have, and the revealer did bring a smile to my face. That‚Äôs about all I ask for in a Monday.

@SP

Fair enough.

@Thad

Your wife/husband/partner must be overjoyed.

@Thad

I finished about as fast as I could type in this thing at just over 4 minutes. Are you using a phone or a physical keyboard?
@Andrzej -- I think the appropriate response is ROFL
@Eli Edwards way to go!

@john ezra

And how did you like the puzzle?
@john ezra Bad Bunny put on an amazing show. And the ending was spectacular with every country in the Americas included. Color me impressed.

@Steve L, I liked it just fine, had a good Word Bank for my riff on the football game! And was amused by the chicken theme, much as I prefer my fowl prepared a little differently than in fingers or strips. But, it being Monday, I got through without a single hiccup. LOL.

@john ezra

What does this have to do with the puzzle? This isn't Facebook lol
@Kristopher, the connection to the puzzle is that I tried to use many of the words in the puzzle in my commentary. It's not much of a connection, I admit, but since you asked, that's the answer!

@john ezra

Completely missed that! Well done! (I need more coffee...)

@john ezra -- It makes my GORGE rise when people choose not  to see the obvious, just because you haven't capitalized on it. Dipping into the Word Bank always blears interest. 
[what the L just happened there?]

Personally think the Stock in Trade should aim for spatchcock.

Enjoyable A-Plus
@Jacqui J I loved Bad Bunny's half-time show, as well! I am not remotely fluent in Spanish, but my language barrier didn't matter even A TAD! I, too, simply loved the ending.

For those who asked what this had to do with the puzzle... "All coach Vrabel could do is wonder [SIC] the sidelines with his CLIPBOARD in RAGS, giving a YELL every now and then. It was a LARGE ORDER to fill."    Good one, @john ezra!
(and that was just the first paragraph!)  :^)
@ST, thanks for that. Also ORCA, NONET, NO WIN, LOST CAUSE, ACNE...(in the first para). Thanks also for catching wonder / wander! When will I learn to spell??

@Steve L I typically start working on a Monday puzzle as soon as it is out at 6 PM ET. But today was Superbowl. So I started on it after the post game. But yes, it was easier than most Monday puzzles.
@Francis ü•∞

@Francis

Really?

@HeathieJ

Really what?  Do I really think the Patriots' football future is brighter than Minnesota's?

Absolutely.

Maybe I didn't state it very well above, but my meaning was that, as a Minnesota fan, I'd love to trade places with a Patriot's fan.

userLocation: ICE in Italia? Basta, ruffiani, fuori!
commentBody:
@Francis
Insofar as I was rooting at all, I was pro Seattle. Not because I know Thing 1 about football, but because the Mariners were such great opponents last summer and their fans were so supportive during the Woeld Series, even after their team lost the AL series to my Blue Jays. So I'm happy to see that their city has a championship team to celebrate this year.

userLocation: ICE in Italia? Basta, ruffiani, fuori!
commentBody:
@Francis
Insofar as I was rooting at all, I was pro Seattle. Not because I know Thing 1 about football, but because the Mariners were such great opponents last summer and their fans were so supportive during the World Series, even after their team lost the AL series to my Blue Jays. So I'm happy to see that their city has a championship team to celebrate this year.

@Francis

Sorry, I was just surprised. I'm just not used to Vikings fans wanting to trade places with anyone, certainly not NE. I generally find them beyond optimistic about the Vikes. 

As for me, as a former Packers fan (gasp - former!?) I haven't watched football in ages and honestly, though I did it out of disgust for the NFL itself and the ridiculous glorification of its athletes, it's been very good for me... kind of like how people talk out here about not caring about their streaks. 

I do want to watch the half-time show though.

userLocation: ICE in Italia? Basta, ruffiani, fuori!
commentBody:
@Francis
Not even as a child when every sunny summer day lasted 28 hours and summer was 14 months long?

@Sam Lyons,

Yes!!! First thing I thought of when I filled it in. OLA, Se√±or GATO!

@NYC Traveler

Se√±or Gato, who always but always answers any human overtures, says Rrrr!
@Sam Lyons: I‚Äôve been addressing Claudius  as ‚Äúmi gato bonito‚Äù and variations as I work my way through Duolingo Spanish. He tolerates my poor accent and poor grammar.

@Sam Lyons

Go Hawks!  And they did.

@kilaueabart

You've somehow avoided fast food, including its advertising, your whole life?!

@Matt

I've never understood the appeal of chicken nuggets. The texture and taste are just off, and that's even if you don't know how they're made. And if you've ever seen how mechanically separated chicken products are manufactured, you should be gagging at the mere sight or mention of nuggets...
@kilaueabart The clue is probably In the 88 years -  at least one of these (chicken nuggets) is ‚Äî I think ‚Äî fast food marketed at kids. The other two are rather foreign to me too.

@Matt

I'll never get how ultra-processed pseuo-food barely fit to be cheap dog feed became an American staple for kids, of all people...

@Francis

Yes, but why would any parent give it to a child? My parents strived to cook simple, healthy food for me. Fatty, cheap and sugary are descriptors of exactly the sort of stuff one should not give children...

@Andrzej

So did mine, but I was pretty lucky.

So here's the situation.  When I went on relic hunting trips with my son in Tennessee, we had to stop and eat.

I could have stopped at a sit-down restaurant, which we sometimes did.  But that way I spent four times as much on a lunch than I would have at an Arby's. 

We seem to be at odds tonight and that makes me nervous, but surely you see the absurdity of a non-parent telling a parent how they should raise their children.

We ate healthy when we could.  The rest of the time we did the best we could.

@Andrzej

When I say "lucky," (and "nowadays") I'm talking about the present situation in the USA, not '80s in Poland.

When I visit the states each year I'm shocked at how expensive healthy food is. In Yokohama I can get a bag of onions or carrots, a head of broccoli or cabbage, a large daikon radish or bunch of 5 beets (the list goes on), each for under US$1

But if living in the states, and both parents working, and healthy food expensive... I can see the appeal of giving kids fast "food"

@Andrzej

Yeah, I know you wrote "we were all poor".  That's what I was trying to emphasize.

Are you enjoying this conversation?  If so, I'll continue.

If not, I won't because it's driving me a bit batty.  

And it's certainly depressing the holy hell out of me.

@Francis

We can agree I'm not enjoying it if that's what you wish.

@kilaueabart
In the days when I was still cooking, I'd often buy raw chicken tenders at the supermarket. They're readily available, and they can be cooked without the need for drowning them in awful oversalted battter or any of the other garbage the fast food places add to them.

@Andrzej

I tried nuggets once in the 80s. I was in a hurry to get somewhere, and didn't have time for a proper lunch, so I pulled into the McDonalds next door and ordered a box. (I was thinking they'd be easier to pop into my mouth one by one - as opposed to managing a burger - while driving).

So back on the road, I pick one up, bite down on it, and ... GAG! 
Greasy. Almost, but not quite, flavorless, and with the glutinous texture of the fat from a slice of ham. ü§Æ

I spit it out, then dumped the rest of the box out the car window for the local gulls to enjoy. 

I haven't touched one since, and I'm happy with that choice.

@Matt

üòÇ  Yes, of course you matter.  I've just reached my limit for the evening!

@Times Rita   @kilaueabart

I think Bart spent most of those years thousands of miles away from mainland US culture whether fast food, pop music, or TV.

That and clean living might explain his longevity.

Glad to see that you're still stopping in Bart.
In the spirit of this season in upstate NY:

Áîü„ÅçÊÆã„ÇäÁîü„Åç
ÊÆã„Çä„Åü„ÇãÂØí„Åï
„Åã„Å™   Issa

Yo ho ho, your groggy self, @Andrew!

otoh, when my childhood self first read Treasure Island, I was very confused by the singing of 'Fifteen men on a dead man's chest' giving me a weird visual, and thinking that must have been very very crowded.

Have I mentioned that English was not my  first language?

@Leapfinger
My first language is English (or Scots) and I thought the same!

@Francis

Dunno about the US but over here a gap year often is not a sign of wealth - on the contrary, students in the worst situation are often forced to take it.

Most of our courses are divided into tiers - tier I is a bachelor's course, and takes 3 years, while tier II is a 2-year master's course.

Some students fail to graduate from tier I in time to be able to register and qualify for tier II. They have no choice but to either abandon university or try to qualify for tier II the following year. They get a gap year,  of sorts, but not because they want to.

Most of our universities are in big cities, which - especially Warsaw - are much more expansive than anywhere else. Many students study for free (the right to a state-provided higher education is enshrined in the constitution), but they have to survive in the cities, with their high rents and expensive food. Most of them need to work to be able to do that. However,  they're young and only able to work part time, so they don't earn as much as they need to survive, let alone thrive. Thus, some take a year off between tier I and tier II to get more full time experience or simply earn more to last the following two years of tier II.

Not all "gap years" are a sign of privilege.

Also, not all well-off people are douches.

@Andrzej

First of all, please don't put words in my mouth:  I never said "all well-off people are douches". 

Second, it's an interesting point about working a gap year in order to have enough money to survive the next years financially.   Obviously, I'm not envious of that situation.

But I never knew any Americans who did that.  I do know a low of people who worked *full time* while attending school.  I didn't, quite.  Most of the time I was in high school and an undergrad, I worked 30-35 hours a weeks, much of the time at two different jobs.  

Moreover, as we don't have free tuition in our Constitution, and because tuition and living expenses are so expensive, it's virtually impossible to save enough during a year of work to fund two (or more) years of school.

Finally, in the US, I never encountered a student who specifically took a gap year for financial reasons.  And I taught at a relatively inexpensive undergrad university with lower to middle class students.  Conversely, gap years were almost always considered a "break", literally the words they used.

I don't want to stir up trouble with you or anyone about this.  I was reporting a gut-level reaction to the experiences I've had with those who took gap years, many of whom accuse me of "wanting everything handed to me" because of my political philosophy.

So, sorry, but sometimes I give into my grievances, too.

@Francis

Why sorry? Why trouble? I just had an addendum to your post.

@Francis

There's a frequest poster here called @Grumpy with whose comments I'm sure you're acquainted.  

You trying to give him a run for his money?

(Besides, Puerto Rico isn't REALLY America...

{wink wink} )

@Matt

I have nothing whatsoever against @Grumpy.  In fact I read his posts eagerly.

I wonder if it's possible for someone not living in a pressure cooker like America to understand that we're just not going to be jolly day after day.

Please don't mistake this as an attack on you, Matt.  I'm simply trying to portray the mindset of a liberal American, who wonders if there is a future for their grandchildren here.  Who wonders what their lives will when we're no longer here to at least try to make it better.

@Francis
Please take this in the best way possible. Have you ever considered spending time somewhere else for a few weeks, just to mix things up? An extended getaway. Somewhere warm, laid back, more rural. Seems to me this "pressure cooker" is largely concentrated in a few cities which dominate the media. I live "out there" and most of the country is relaxed, friendly and enjoyable.

@Hanson

You do know that Francis does not live in an urban part of Minnesota?

@Heidi
I follow the news. Problem is, is that there is an unlimited amount of bandwidth and only so much content. The same thing gets fed over and over and over and over again and multiplied by algorithms that drive the same. It drives people nuts. I'm simply suggesting, for anyone, it might be good to disrupt the cycle.

@Francis I think it's more common here in the US to work between the undergraduate and graduate degrees. High school grads don't have a lot of options for jobs other than minimum wage, while college grads may have more. I worked full-time in the university library while earning my MLS, then worked for 10 years before going back to school full-time for my PhD.

@Suzanne

Thanks. I thought I might have been missing something in my own imperfect translation. 

Over here no leave of absence between tier I and II studies needs to be taken. Once you're done with tier I, you can continue onto tier II but only if you want to, and if you met the criteria. Some people end their higher education at tier I, some continue with tier II straight away, some take a year to work, etc.

Also, we all get a gap quarter - longer in fact. High school ends in late spring, and university classes begin in October. High school graduates who continue their education get some 4 months of time to do with as they please. Some loaf around - I know I did - others get their first (usually temporary) job.

@Hanson
Amen and amen

@Francis

I hear you.

I have split my life fairly evenly between two countries which, until fairly recently, were always only surreptitiously fascist and only fairly recently have become overtly fascist and proud of their respective xenophobias.

I have no encouraging words for you other than the usual historian spiel about pendula...

@Francis

I, too, was envious after high school of all my well-off friends who did gap years.

I comforted myself with the disparaging thought that I would get a temporal leg up on all of them when I eventually succeeded in my chosen career.

Ludicrously sour grapes, of course.

@Francis
I spent four GAP YEARs in the Army between HS and university, which meant I didn't have student loan debt, I didn't have to live in a dorm, and I could legally drink. I am firmly convinced that 17 year old me would have done terribly as a freshman. I recommend the experience.

@Hanson

Thank you very much for the really good points, questions, and advice, offered I think in a spirit of understanding.  I truly do appreciate it, cross my heart.

I split my time between Minneapolis (suburbs, actually) and Grand Marais, which is kind of rural, except that I generally don't think of seaside places as rural.

I don't compartmentalize very well.  If I'm unhappy about one aspect of my life, I can't shed it just by thinking about something else.

It's not that the people in my immediate vicinity are causing the problem--the problem is the presence of what the right used to call "jacŒ∫-Œ≤ooted thugs".  And it doesn't matter where they are operating.  The fact that there are federal agents anywhere in the country given a license to kill, followed immediately by character assassination of the dead, distresses me where ever it's happening.

I don't know if you was you or Jerry that made the point that the media loves to just whip us up into a frenzy, but it's a terrific one.  The problem is there's just too much money to be made by making people angry with one another.  Some people made a fortune stirring up controversy with a former president and first lady photoshopped onto simian bodies.  Things like that are gold mines for people of very low moral character.

So I can't escape it that easily.  I can't forget about it that easily.  

But I do appreciate your thoughts, and welcome a continuing conversation, honest and thoughtful.

@Jerry

Yes, I've known students like you describe, scrambling for an education.  

Like most everything else, my objection to "gap year" affluenza (great word) is not absolute.  Virtually none of my opinions are absolute.  So I'm sure there are many quite wonderful, worthy people who've used a gap year for true growth and development.  My closest friend in grad school took a year or so off between undergraduate and graduate school to work in the Peace Corps.  My ht is off to time because a year in Ghana would have driven my crazy.

I hope we can continue to share thoughts without rancor.

@Francis
Most of the people I know use the Gap Year after undergrad to go to work and earn money or get work experience to go on to grad school.  There is a wonderful organization called City Year which recruits Gap Year young people to work as aids in classrooms where students need more help.
@John Depends really, can range from dust, flakes, pickers (which are just miniature nuggets) and if you're lucky/panning in the right spot, actual nuggets

@John

How big does a piece of gold--or chicken, for that matter--have to be to technically qualify as a nugget?

@Elena thanks for solving! Give STL a hug for me, I loved living there

@Elena

Happy birthday, Elena! I hope you get to do something equally fun today.
@MStock  I will! I‚Äôm sure STL loves you back!

@Elena

@Shelby
So glad you wrote in. I was feeling guilty about liking chicken objects. Granted, I buy mine retail in a deli and not at a fast food outlet, so they're slightly less industrial. (And how right it is to refer to those places as "outlets", rather than restaurants.)  But I'm a fan of crunchiness in all its forms: grid fill, fried chicken bits, veggies.

Leapfinger,

I think most people raised in hockey first thought ‚Äúwhat is tacked on to ‚Äògoalie‚Äô there?‚Äù. And personally, goalkeeper makes me think more of non-super football than hockey. But maybe there are regional differences around the rinks.

Goalkeeper for soccer, goaltender for hockey, but commonly shortened to goalie. (I've played both sports.)
